Lesson 10: Cases in German

German has only four cases:

  • Nominativ
  • Akkusativ
  • Dativ
  • Genitiv

At A1 level, we focus only on the first three: Nominativ, Akkusativ, and Dativ.

🧠 What Are 'Cases'?

We already understand cases from English — we just don’t name them.

In any sentence, we can identify:

  • Subject – the one who does something
  • Object – the thing something is done to
  • Indirect Object – the one who receives or benefits indirectly

Example:
Hasan gives Amo a mango.
Hasan = subject, Amo = indirect object, mango = object

Cases and Sentence Roles

Each sentence role matches a case in German:

  • Subject → Nominativ
  • Direct Object → Akkusativ
  • Indirect Object → Dativ

📌 Quick Revision: Direct vs Indirect Object

Example:

He gives a ball to the boy.
“A ball” = direct object
“The boy” = indirect object

Direct object = what is being given.
Indirect object = who receives it.

🔍 Gender and Objects in German

In German, even non-living things have gender:

  • die Uhr (the watch) → feminine
  • der Ball (the ball) → masculine
  • das Auto (the car) → neuter

You must learn the gender of each noun.

📘 German Cases Table

Here is how the definite articles change based on case in German. These are useful to identify the subject (Nominative), direct object (Accusative), and indirect object (Dative) in a sentence.


(S) here refers to Singular

CaseMasculine (s)Feminine (s)Neuter (s)Plural
Nominative
(Subject)		derdiedasdie
Accusative
(Direct Object)		dendiedasdie
Dative
(Indirect Object)		demderdemden

🧠 Tip: Use this table to match the case based on function in the sentence:
— Nominative: Who or what is doing the action?
— Accusative: What is being directly acted upon?
— Dative: To whom or for whom?

💡 How to Use the Table

In the beginning, you can refer to the table often — that’s okay!

With practice, it becomes second nature. Let’s try some easy nominative sentences first.

Remember:

  • Ball = masculine
  • Uhr = feminine
  • Auto = neuter

🟢 Nominativ Examples

The ball is red.
Ball = subject → Nominativ → masculine → der
Der Ball ist rot.

The watch is red.
Uhr = feminine → die
Die Uhr ist rot.

The car is red.
Auto = neuter → das
Das Auto ist rot.

🔴 Akkusativ Examples (Object)

I have the ball.
“I” = subject → Nominativ
“The ball” = object → Akkusativ → masculine → den
Ich habe den Ball.

I have the watch.
Ich habe die Uhr.

I have the car.
Ich habe das Auto.

📌 Summary

  • German uses cases to mark the function of words in a sentence.
  • Nominativ = subject
  • Akkusativ = direct object
  • Dativ = indirect object
  • Learn noun gender and check the case table to choose correct articles (der/die/das etc).

Let’s now do some exercises!
